The oxidation of carbon monoxide (CO) has garnered significant interest for its application in treating automobile exhaust. In this study, we employed the sol-gel method to synthesize a series of cobalt-zirconium oxide catalysts with various Co/Zr ratios, aiming to catalyze the oxidation of CO effectively. The findings showed that the Co90Zr10 catalyst, with a cobalt-to-zirconium ratio of 90:10, not only exhibited exceptional catalytic efficiency, achieving a 90 % conversion of CO at 94 °C, but also sustained superior thermal stability and resistance to water. The presence of both cobalt defects and oxygen vacancies significantly enhances the catalytic activity, which is attributed to the doping of zirconium. The characterization analyses indicated the incorporation of zirconium into the Co3O4 spinel lattice modifies the valence states (Co3+/Co2+) and geometries (CoOh/CoTd) of the cobalt cations. This alteration results from a variety of partial electron transfers and substitution sites. Enhanced ratios of Co3+/Co2+ and CoOh/CoTd in the CoxZry catalysts lead to improved reducibility and oxygen mobility. Consequently, this facilitates the lower-temperature oxidation of intermediates during the catalytic conversion of CO. DFT result showed that the Co3O4 after Zr doped has lower adsorption energy and revealed the reaction mechanism of CO catalytic oxidation. This difficulty arises from the strong adsorption of CO on the active sites of noble metal catalysts, which often leads to catalyst deactivation [1,2]. The total catalytic oxidation is a well-established method for removing CO and is considered the most effective approach for eliminating pollutants at low temperatures [3-5]. Transition metal oxides, particularly cobalt oxide, are regarded as promising catalysts following noble metals due to their exceptional low-temperature oxidation activity [6-8]. Tuning catalyst morphology and doping second metal are common methods to improve catalytic activity. Cai et al. [9] synthesized a series of ultrathin, polycrystalline, two-dimensional (2D) Co3O4 with a high BET surface area, giving a high catalytic activity for CO oxidation. Bae et al. [10] reported a bimetallic oxide for the catalytic oxidation of CO, by doping La into Co3O4, enhanced the activity and water-resistant during the catalytic process. Despite intensive studies, factors affecting catalyst activity at the microscale are still controversial, such as the role of different oxygen species, oxygen vacancies, Co3+/Co2+ and exposed facets [11,12]. Recent research has revealed that CO oxidation catalyzed by Co3O4 follows the typical Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism [13]. This process involves the reaction of CO molecules with surface lattice oxygen atoms associated with Co3+ cations. The oxygen vacancies generated through this reaction are subsequently filled by gaseous oxygen. [14,15]. This reaction mechanism underscores the dynamic characteristics of the catalytic process. During this process, the active oxide species undergo structural and surface state transformations, which are influenced by various reaction conditions such as temperature and the relative concentrations of O2 and CO gases. Grasping the dynamic oxidation states at the catalyst surface or the metal-oxide juncture is pivotal for catalytic performance optimization. Within this framework, the augmentation of Co3O4 catalytic prowess through integration with other metal oxides has been explored. For instance, Li et al. [16] have shown that the addition of CeO2 to Co3O4 (forming Co3O4−CeO2 catalysts) significantly lowers the reduction temperature of Co3O4. The addition of other metal oxides to Co3O4 not only enhances its preferential oxidation activity for CO but also suggests that the specific interfacial interaction between the two metal oxides contributes to the stabilization of the oxidation state in Co3O4. The rationale behind the choice of ZrO2 Co3O4 lies in the unique properties of ZrO2, which include high thermal stability and resistance to chemical corrosion [17]. When combined with Co3O4, these properties could potentially enhance the overall stability and efficiency of the catalyst. Xia et al. [18] used Zr doped Ce2Co1Ox catalyst to explore the mechanism of doping on oxygen vacancy defects and thus affect the catalytic oxidation performance of toluene. The mechanism and deactivation process of Mn-Zr metal oxide catalyzed the oxidation of vinyl chloride revealed the principle of Zr in catalytic reaction [19]. Moreover, ZrO2 is recognized for its oxygen storage capacity, which could play a crucial role in facilitating the oxygen transfer mechanisms essential for efficient CO oxidation. This aspect is particularly crucial in the context of the MvK mechanism, where replenishing oxygen vacancies is key to sustaining catalytic activity due to its dynamic nature. However, studies on Zr-doped transition metal catalysts are scarce, especially for short-chain contaminants. In this work, we synthesize CoxZry catalysts using advanced materials processing techniques to achieve optimal dispersion and interaction between the two oxides. Our aim is to investigate the structural, electronic, and surface properties of the composite catalyst and to understand how these properties influence its catalytic performance. We focus on examining the effects of ZrO2 addition on the redox behavior, oxygen vacancy formation, and the distribution of Co3+ and Co2+ oxidation states. Moreover, the study seeks to understand the role of ZrO2 in enhancing the catalyst's resistance to deactivation, particularly under challenging environmental conditions. By conducting thorough experimental analyses and characterizations, we aim to elucidate the underlying mechanisms of the CoxZry catalyst in the oxidation of CO. The findings from this study have the potential to substantially advance the development of catalysts that are more effective, durable, and economical for environmental cleanup, with a particular focus on mitigating CO emissions from industrial and automotive sources. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst syntheses A series of spinel oxide samples with varying Co/Zr molar ratios were synthesized using a method similar to that described in our previous study [17], as shown in Scheme 1 . Initially, a solution containing 0.019 mol of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.001 mol of Zr(NO3)4·5H2O, and 0.03 mol of citric acid was prepared in 50 mL of deionized water. The solution was maintained at 80 °C with constant stirring for 8 h to yield a gel, which underwent drying at 100 °C over a period of 24 h. Following this step, the dried gel was subjected to calcination at 400 °C under static air for 4 h, with a temperature increase of 4 °C per minute. The synthesized catalyst was designated as Co95Zr5. Other catalysts, denoted as CoxZry, were prepared in a similar manner, where x/y represents the nominal Co/Zr molar ratio in each catalyst. 2.2 Characterizations The synthesized samples were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a Rigaku TTR-III diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 200 mA, λ=0.154056 nm), covering a 2θ range from 10° to 80° Chemical composition and elemental states were assessed with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) on a Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi, employing monochromatic Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV). For the full spectrum analysis, a transmission energy of 160 eV was used, while narrow scans utilized an analyzer pass energy of 40 eV. Binding energies were calibrated using the C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurements were carried out using a Micromeritics Tristar II 3020 M to evaluate the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area and porosity of the catalyst samples at −196 °C. Before conducting the measurements, all samples underwent degassing at 200 °C for 3 h to remove any adsorbed substances. Nitrogen isotherms were then recorded in both adsorption and desorption modes. The surface area of the samples was calculated using the BET method. The total pore volume was derived from the volume of vapor adsorbed at a relative pressure of 0.995. Additionally, the pore size distribution was inferred from the desorption branches of the isotherms, utilizing the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS, using Oxford Aztec software) mapping images were captured using a GeminiSEM 500, operating at 200 kV. For the SEM analysis, the samples were sprinkled onto adhesive conductive carbon paper which was then mounted on brass stubs. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images were taken with a JEM-2100PLUS, also operating at 200 kV. For TEM analysis, the samples were homogeneously dispersed in ethanol, and a droplet of the resultant suspension was deposited onto copper grids. Following air drying, the grids were inserted into the TEM sample holder to facilitate imaging. This method provides detailed insight into the morphology and elemental composition of the catalysts at the micro and nano scales. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) analyses were conducted using a Nicolet 8700 to provide a qualitative evaluation of the elemental composition of the samples. Additionally, Raman spectroscopy was performed using a LabRamHR Evolution laser Raman spectrometer, utilizing an excitation wavelength of 532 nm. To investigate the changes in oxygen species at different temperatures, the samples were heated from 25 °C to 150 °C under an atmosphere containing 20 vol.% O2. This approach allows for the monitoring of dynamic changes in the chemical environment of the samples, particularly focusing on oxygen-related functional groups. H2 chemisorption experiments were carried out to evaluate the number of active sites in the catalysts using a BELCAT II instrument. The method involved pulse injection of hydrogen. Each catalyst sample, weighing 50 mg, underwent a pretreatment at 573 K for 1 hour under a mixture of 20 % O2 and He at a flow rate of 50 mL/min to remove any organic surfactants. Following this, the catalyst was cooled to 193 K. Hydrogen pulses were then injected into the cell under a continuous flow of helium. The experimental parameters for the H2 chemisorption included a hydrogen concentration of 5 % in the pulse, a total flow rate balanced with helium at 50 mL/min, a pulse size of 0.4 mL, and a time interval between pulses of 4 min. This procedure helps to ascertain the catalyst's active site density, crucial for understanding its effectiveness in catalytic processes. X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectra were obtained at the 1W1B beamline of the Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility (BSRF). The Co K-edge spectra of the samples and reference compounds were recorded in transmission mode at room temperature. Additionally, experiments involving synchrotron radiation softeners were conducted at the National Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory. 2.3 Catalytic reactions The catalytic oxidation experiments of CO employing CoxZry catalysts were performed in a continuous-flow, fixed-bed reactor with a 5.7 mm internal diameter. For these experiments, 100 mg of the catalyst powders, sieved to a 60–80 mesh size, were used. The reaction mixture consisted of 1 vol.% CO, 20 vol.% O2, and the balance was Argon, with a flow rate set at 100 mL/min. This configuration yield a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 60,000 mLgcat −1h−1. The gaseous effluent from the reactor was analyzed using an online gas chromatography system, specifically an Agilent 7820 equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Each sample was allowed to stabilize for 0.5 h at the set temperature before analysis to ensure a static state for accurate measurements. Upon reaching a stable state, the samples were subjected to analysis at each designated temperature, producing three consistent sets of analytical data. Following each analysis, the temperature was incrementally raised to the next level to continue the reaction process. After a suitable stabilization period at each new temperature, allowing the system to reach a steady state once more, the analysis procedure was repeated. This stepwise approach allows for detailed characterization of the catalyst's performance across a range of temperatures, providing comprehensive data on its effectiveness in catalyzing CO oxidation. 2.4 Computational calculation The spin polarization was calculated using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [20]. All calculations in this study were performed within the theoretical framework of Density Functional Theory (DFT). The Projected Augmented Wave (PAW) method was employed to characterize the interactions between the valence electrons and nuclei [21,22]. The exchange-correlation term was described using the Generalized Gradient Approximation (GGA). Specifically, the Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) generalized function was employed [23]. In the DFT calculations, the valence electrons for cobalt (Co 3d, 4 s), oxygen (O 2 s, 2p), and zirconium (Zr 4d, 5 s) were treated at a plane-wave cutoff energy of 400 eV. To enhance the accuracy of these calculations, a Hubbard U term was added to the Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) function within the framework of DFT+U. This adjustment employs the rotationally invariant formalism proposed by Dudarev et al. [24,25]. A Ueff value of 3.30 eV was used to describe the 3d state of Co, which has been shown to accurately characterize the electronic structure of Co [26]. On the basis of experimental characterization, we considered the (100) surface of Co3O4. A plate comprising 8 layers was designed with a transverse p (2 × 2) surface unit to closely represent the surface structure. To prevent any artificial interactions between replicated plates in the periodic boundary conditions, a vacuum layer of 20 Å was incorporated. During geometry optimization, to ensure the reliability and accuracy of the simulation, stringent convergence tolerances were employed. The energy tolerance was set at 1 × 10−5 eV and the maximum force tolerance was maintained at 0.01 eV/Å, respectively. Finally, The Brillouin zone (BZ) was sampled using a 4 × 4 × 1 Gamma grid. Transition states for the CO oxidation reaction were identified using the Climbing Image Induced Elastic Band (CI-NEB) and DIMER methods [27-29]. The structure of the transition state is defined by the imaginary frequency and its corresponding vibrational direction. The adsorped energy (Eads) is calculated using the following formula: (1) E a d s = E A + E B − E A B Where EA, EB, and EAB represent the energy of molecules adsorbed on the surface, the substrate, and the complete adsorption system, respectively. The calculation of energy barrier and heat of reaction is described as follows: (2) E a = E T S − E I S (3) Δ E a = E F S − E I S Where ETS is the transition state energy and EIS is the initial reactant energy. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Structural characterization of CoxZry samples A series of zirconium-doped cobalt tetraoxide samples were prepared via a sol-gel method. As the Zr/Co ratio increased, significant changes were observed in the textural properties of the samples. As the amount of zirconium doping increases, the characteristic peaks belonging to Co3O4 (JCPDS PDF# 42–1407) appear to be significantly weakened, as shown in Fig. 1 b. Zirconium atoms may have replaced some Co atoms in the Co3O4 lattice, or doping layers may have formed at lattice interstitial locations, which may have caused lattice distortion and thus reduced the intensity of the XRD characteristic peaks [30]. Different from previous work [17], the introduction of zirconium does not produce obvious characteristic peaks belonging to ZrO2, which may be due to the low doping amount of zirconium. The adsorption-desorption isotherms of both Co3O4 and CoxZry exhibit type IV isotherms, along with H3-type hysteresis loops (Fig. S2), Fig. 1c shows that as the zirconium doping amount increases, the Sbet of the synthesized catalyst gradually increases (from 31.5 to 76.3 m2/g). The higher specific surface area may be related to higher defect levels within the material, which include lattice distortion and defects such as vacancies and dislocations [31]. These structural defects can reduce the XRD peak intensity of specific crystal planes because they change the periodicity and X-ray scattering ability of the lattice planes [32]. TEM images of catalysts with varying doping ratios are depicted in Fig. 1a, the incorporation of zirconium is posited to enhance the homogeneous dispersion of Co3O4, which in turn may lead to diminished particle sizes and augmented specific surface areas. This higher degree of dispersion can reduce the diffraction intensity of certain crystallographic planes in XRD because there may be more random distribution of crystallographic plane directions. The HRTEM image of Co3O4, displayed in Fig. 1d, reveals a cubic lattice with an inter-planar distance of 0.243 nm, which corresponds to the (311) plane of the Co3O4 spinel, consistent with the XRD profile at 36.9° Meanwhile, the deposited ZrO2 layer exhibits small aggregated clusters with distinct grain boundaries, indicating aggregation-based growth (Fig. 1e). Elemental mapping analyses conducted in STEM-EDS mode, as depicted in Fig. 1f, reveal numerous defective channels on the catalyst surface, with different crystal planes belonging to Co3O4 and ZrO2 exposed on both the catalyst and defective surfaces (Fig. S2). These findings provide strong evidence for the presence of Co3O4-ZrO2 composite structures. To further elucidate the composition of surface-bound oxygen species and the distribution of charges, we performed X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis. As illustrated in Fig. 2 b, the spectra showed three distinct peaks: one at 529.6 eV due to lattice oxygen (OL), one at 531.4 eV due to the adsorbed oxygen species at the surface defect sites i.e. oxygen vacancies (OV), and one at 532.5 eV due to the hydroxyl species of the surface-adsorbed water molecules (OW) [33,34]. The OV (%) was calculated by the following formula, OV= OV/ (OL+ OV+ OW) [35] and the result was shown in Table 1 . The recorded values were 32, 36, 40 and 41 % for Co3O4, Co99Zr1, Co95Zr5 and Co90Zr10 respectively. These results suggest that oxygen vacancies were successfully introduced into the catalysts. Fig. 2a exhibits the Co 2p XPS spectra, with the characteristic peaks at 779.8 and 795.0 eV corresponding to Co3+, and the peaks at 781.3 and 796.5 eV to Co2+. The calculated relative atomic ratio of Co3+ to Co2+ is delineated in Table 1.The result shows that the synthesized catalysts had higher Co3+ species and with the introduction of zirconium, the Co3+/Co2+increases (from 1.46 to 1.58, 1.49 and 1.52). The Co3+ species, known for its superior redox properties, plays a significant role in the catalytic oxidation of CO. In Fig. 1c, we observe two prominent peaks at 181.4 eV and 184.2 eV in the Zr 3d spectra of the samples, which correspond to the Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 states, respectively. Owing to the subtle shifts in binding energies among various zirconium species, these peaks can be further resolved into components attributed to Zrδ+ and Zr4+ ions. This finding further corroborates the formation of a ZrO2 Co3O4 solid solution. In-depth investigation into the surface functional groups and the electronic configuration was performed using FTIR spectra, as depicted in Fig. 2a. It is clear that each sample displays vibrational peaks at 586 cm−1 and 672 cm−1, which correspond to the Co3+-O and Co2+-O bonds, respectively. These findings corroborate the establishment of the Co3O4 crystal structure. Furthermore, the peaks at 1632 cm−1 and 3432 cm−1 are indicative of OH bond vibrations in the surface hydroxyl groups. [36,37]. The characteristics associated with Co3+-O and Co2+-O decrease with the increase of zirconium doping. This suggests that zirconium doping can influence the adsorption characteristics of the catalyst surface, particularly the adsorption of oxygen species. Consequently, this may impact the surface concentration or chemical state of Co2+ and Co3+ ions. Raman spectra revealed five distinct bands at 189, 472, 507, 604, and 670 cm−1, corresponding to the F2g (1), E2g, F2g (2), F2g (3), and A1g symmetry, respectively (Fig. 2e), indicating that all samples possess the spinel structure. The slight red-shift observed can be attributed to residual stress and lattice distortion following zirconium substitution into the Co3O4 spinel. The in situ variable-temperature Raman spectra of the Co90Zr10 catalyst (Fig. 2f) exhibit peak shifts towards lower wavenumbers at 465 and 673 cm−1, corresponding to highly charged Co ions. Conversely, the peak at 507 cm−1 associated with Co2+ remains relatively unchanged with increasing temperature from 50 to 175 °C under the atmosphere of 10 % O2/Ar. The results indicate that, within the Co90Zr10 catalyst, Co3+ ions adopting octahedral coordination exhibit greater instability and reactivity compared to Co2+ ions with tetrahedral coordination, owing to lattice distortion at the reaction temperature. [16]. Synchrotron radiation XAS was conducted to investigate the variation of the electronic and atomic structure. In the Co-L2,3 edge spectra (Fig. 3 a), three dominant peaks were observed, including the Co-L3 edge at approximately 789 eV, a prominent shoulder at approximately 787 eV, and the Co-L2 edge at approximately 803 eV. Upon doping with zirconium, a discernible alteration at the Co-L3 edge is evident, manifested as a increase of feature b. This alteration signals the emergence of low-coordinated octahedral Co2+ ions, corroborating the formation of oxygen vacancies [38]. In O-K edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectroscopy (Fig. 3b), the pre-edge peak a is indicative of electron transitions to the hole states in the Co 3d-O 2p octahedral coordination. [39,40]. Noticeably, with the increase of zirconium doping, the intensity of peak a increased, owing to the introduction of numerous oxygen vacancies. However, the increasing feature of Co90Zr10 is much more pronounced than Co3O4 in both Co-L3 and O-K edge spectra at the same scale. The observation indicates that the presence of cobalt defects likely promotes the concurrent formation of oxygen vacancies. We further investigated the valence distribution of CoxZry catalysts by examining the Co K-edge XANES spectrum, (Fig. 3c). The sequence of the Co cation valence states, as inferred from the Co-K edge position in Fig. 3c, is as follows: Co3O4 > Co90Zr10, indicating a decreased Co3+/Co2+ ratio in Co90Zr10. The geometry distribution of CoxZry catalysts was also explored by extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra analysis. The radial distances in Fig. 3d are the apparent distance with a difference of 0.3–0.4 Å to the real bond distance. In the EXAFS spectra of the Co-K edge, three typical peaks are observed: the first peaks below 2 Å are attributable to the Co-O coordination shell, reflecting the scattering from the nearest-neighbor lattice oxygen atoms surrounding the absorber; meanwhile, the peaks at approximately 2.5 Å are indicative of the CoOh −MOh interactions within the octahedral sites, revealing scattering between the metal cation and its closest neighboring metal cations. The peaks at around 3.0 Å are related to the CoTd −MOh/MTd shell, representing scattering from the metal cation to the closest neighbor metal cations around tetrahedral sites [41,42]. These results indicate that Co cations are distributed in both the octahedral and tetrahedral sites of Co90Zr10. 3.2 Catalytic performance of CoxZry catalysts in Co oxidation The catalytic efficacy of the synthesized CoxZry catalysts for CO oxidation was evaluated over a temperature range of 50–150 °C, employing a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 120,000 mLgcat−1h−1. (Fig. 4 a). Remarkably, Zr substitution significantly promoted the catalytic oxidation of CO. The T50 and T90 values are shown in Fig. 4b, where the Co90Zr10 catalyst exhibited excellent low-temperature CO oxidation activity with T50 of 67 °C and T90 of 94 °C, while the Co3O4 catalyst exhibited T50 values of 98 °C and T90 of 123 °C. The Co99Zr1 and Co95Zr5 catalysts show similar performance (T50 of 82 and 81 °C, T90 of 104 and 112 °C), and both better than Co3O4 sample. As seen in Fig. 4d, a long-term stability test of Co90Zr10 for CO catalytic oxidation, the CO conversion rate of Co90Zr10 can be stabilized above 98 % under a continuous gas atmosphere (1 % CO, 20 % O2 and Ar as balance), which exhibits outstanding catalytic stability. Next, the long-term water resistance of Co90Zr10 for CO catalytic oxidation was inspected at 95 °C for 30 h (Fig. 4e). When 5.0 vol% water vapor was introduced, there was a distinct decline in catalytic performance, with CO conversion decreasing from 91 % to 72 %, accompanied by a deactivation rate of approximately 21 %. However, upon removal of the water, the activity rapidly restored. The CO oxidation results for the CoxZry catalysts, including turnover frequency (TOF), Arrhenius plot, and activation energy in the 65–105 °C temperature range, are presented in Fig. 4c, f, and Table S2, respectively. The TOF values of the CoxZry catalysts were significantly enhanced at all temperatures compared to pristine Co3O4 without ZrO2 deposition. Notably, Co90Zr10 exhibited a TOF of 9.04 s −1 at 95 °C, notably higher than that of Co3O4 (2.96 s −1). The activation energy obtained from the Arrhenius plots shows that Co90Zr10 (32.9 kJ/mol) exhibits a lower activation energy compared to pristine Co3O4 (99.0 kJ/mol), demonstrating the interfacial effect resulting from ZrO2 deposition on Co3O4 (Fig. 4f). The comparative catalytic performance results for Co90Zr10 and several other transition metal oxide catalysts reported in the literature are summarized in Table 2 . The Co90Zr10 catalyst demonstrates superior catalytic effects compared to other similar metal-doped catalysts. These findings suggest that CoxZry catalysts are highly efficient and cost-effective, with the potential for practical applications as alternatives to precious metal catalysts. 3.3 Reaction mechanism in Co oxidation over CoXZrY catalysts The adsorption energy of O2 and CO over Co3O4 and CoxZry catalyst was shown in Fig. 5 . It can be observed that CO tends to adsorb on Co atoms with an adsorption energy of − 1.12 eV on the Co3O4 surface (Fig. 5b) and − 1.45 eV on the CoxZry surface (Fig. 5d). The adsorption energy of CO adsorbed by zirconium doping decreased significantly, implying that the adsorbed CO was easier to activate. Similarly, Fig. 5a and c depict the adsorption energy of O2 on the surface of Co3O4 and CoxZry. The formation of two Co-O bonds resulted in a higher adsorption energy on the surface of Co3O4 (−0.80 eV), while a single Zr-O bond exhibited an energy of −1.45 eV. This finding suggests easier activation of oxygen on the surface of the CoxZry catalyst, which may be a crucial step in the catalytic reaction [44]. The optimal reaction pathway for CO on CoxZry (200) is illustrated in Fig. 6 . CO adsorbs on the Co site adjacent to the Zr atom with an adsorption energy of −1.45 eV. Subsequently, O is connected via Co-O-Zr, with only an energy barrier of 0.635 eV needing to be overcome. The process from initial state (IM1) through the transition state (TS1) to intermediate state (IM2) is exothermic, with an energy release of 0.857 eV, indicating that Zr doping enhances the activity of lattice oxygen. According to the MvK reaction mechanism [45], O2 molecules fill the defects, with the adsorbed O2 being activated and connected in parallel with Zr. Meanwhile, CO on the Co atom continues to react with O2*, leading to the breaking of the OO bond and approaching CO* with a transition state energy barrier of 0.05 eV. This exothermic reaction produces CO2 with an energy of 0.693 eV, followed by desorption to gaseous CO2, thus completing the catalytic cycle of the catalyst. Through this analysis, it is evident that the reaction process of CO primarily occurs on the surface of CoxZry (200). The 0.635 eV reaction energy barrier for the rate-limiting step suggests that Zr doping enhances the cobalt redox capability in the catalytic cycle. 4 Conclusion In summary, a series of low-doped cobalt-zirconium oxide catalysts were synthesized via the sol-gel method. Notably, the Co90Zr10 catalyst exhibited remarkable activity at low temperatures, achieving T50 and T90 values of 67 °C and 94 °C, respectively. At 95 °C, the Co90Zr10 catalyst demonstrated an apparent reaction rate of 6.12 (× 10−4) mol g −1s−1, the lowest activation energy of 32.9 kJ/mol, and a TOF of 9.04 s −1. SEM, TEM, and BET analyses revealed that the addition of Zr led to an increase in surface area and mesoporous volume, significantly enhancing catalytic performance. Moreover, the incorporation of Zr into the lattice induced additional oxygen vacancy creation, by altering the chemical environment of the spinel, which substantiated by Raman spectroscopy and XPS findings. The improved catalytic efficacy of CoxZry stems from an increased CoOh/CoTd ratio due to Zr substitution at both CoOh and CoTd sites, as well as a higher Co3+/Co2+ ratio resulting from partial electron transfer between Zr and Co cations via adjacent lattice oxygen. These factors contribute to enhanced reducibility and oxygen mobility, as evidenced by FTIR, XPS, and XAS analyses. DFT simulations revealed that O2 and CO exhibit enhanced adsorption on the surface of the CoxZry catalyst after Zr doping, elucidating the CO catalytic oxidation pathways via the MvK mechanism. This study holds significant implications for the design of bimetal oxide catalysts and the mitigation of short-chain pollutants. coredata.dc:description: The oxidation of carbon monoxide (CO) has garnered significant interest for its application in treating automobile exhaust. In this study, we employed the sol-gel method to synthesize a series of cobalt-zirconium oxide catalysts with various Co/Zr ratios, aiming to catalyze the oxidation of CO effectively. The findings showed that the Co90Zr10 catalyst, with a cobalt-to-zirconium ratio of 90:10, not only exhibited exceptional catalytic efficiency, achieving a 90 % conversion of CO at 94 °C, but also sustained superior thermal stability and resistance to water. The presence of both cobalt defects and oxygen vacancies significantly enhances the catalytic activity, which is attributed to the doping of zirconium. The characterization analyses indicated the incorporation of zirconium into the Co3O4 spinel lattice modifies the valence states (Co3+/Co2+) and geometries (CoOh/CoTd) of the cobalt cations. This alteration results from a variety of partial electron transfers and substitution sites. Enhanced ratios of Co3+/Co2+ and CoOh/CoTd in the CoxZry catalysts lead to improved reducibility and oxygen mobility. Consequently, this facilitates the lower-temperature oxidation of intermediates during the catalytic conversion of CO. DFT result showed that the Co3O4 after Zr doped has lower adsorption energy and revealed the reaction mechanism of CO catalytic oxidation.
